newsitem.title: JAPAN: Lawyer says Japan copper trader helping officials.
newsitem.headline: Lawyer says Japan copper trader helping officials.

text.p: Former star copper trader Yasuo Hamanaka is voluntarily cooperating with Japanese prosecutors investigating Sumitomo Corp's trading losses of $2.6 billion, one of his lawyers said on Thursday.

"Hamanaka told me he's now spending about eight hours a day on the investigation with the prosecutors. He is voluntarily cooperating," said Toru Yoshiki, one of the three lawyers representing Hamanaka.
Hamanaka was arrested last week after Sumitomo filed a complaint saying he forged documents to give himself authorisation to conduct certain copper trades.
The giant trading house has accused Hamanaka of racking up the huge losses from unauthorised copper trading.
Before Sumitomo fired him in mid-June, Hamanaka was considered the most influential and controversial player in the world copper market.
Traders called him "Mr Five Percent" because of the chunk of the global copper market that he was said to control.
Hamanaka is being held in a Tokyo detention centre. "His family sent some clothes and food, but has had no opportunity to meet him so far," Yoshiki said. -- Tokyo Commodities Desk +81-3-3432-7391
